Welcome to the wond=
erful world of JUnit!

There are many useful websites for the JUnit user, b=
ut perhaps the two
main ones are http://www.junit.org/ and http://www.googl=
e.com/.

The JUnit site maintains a lot of useful information and links to
=
other resources. Many of the articles there are directed towards the
beginn=
er and will help you greatly as you learn about JUnit. There is
even a link=
 on the site called "Getting Started" that will take you to
a page full of =
useful information for those who wish to learn to use
JUnit.

Google is use=
ful when there's something you need, but don't know what
it is. Just type a=
 description in, press enter and see how much help
it can be. I've found qu=
ite a few useful things that way. Another tip
with Google is to search on t=
he specific error message that you have,
often you'll find forum discussion=
s about that exact error, with a
good chance of a solution being given as w=
ell.

As you learn and start having questions, you will also find the JUnit=

FAQ very helpful. The questions that it answers really are the
frequent on=
es that most of us had asked or wondered about and Mike
Clark does a wonder=
ful job of collating it. Here is a link:

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/=
faq/faq.htm

When you are ready to start asking more questions on the JUnit=
 mailing
list, please consider following all of the advice in Eric Raymond'=
s
very helpful document: "How to ask questions the smart way", available
at=
 his website. Here is a link:

http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-question=
s.html

As far as books are concerned, I recommend Pragmatic Unit Testing b=
y
Hunt and Thomas for beginners. JUnit recipes by Rainsberger is good
once =
you're past the basics. There are other good books out there, but
these are=
 my recommendations.

I hope that this helps.

Simon
